question: For a patient with stage IIIA non-small cell lung cancer (T1–2, N2) and an R1 resection margin after surgery, if consolidation chemoradiation is considered, does this implicitly require the absence of distant metastases at the time of initiation?

Recurrence • FDG-PET/CT • Brain MRI with contrastq

answer: Yes, consolidation chemoradiation after an R1 resection in stage IIIA non-small cell lung cancer is indicated only in the absence of distant metastases, as its intent is local-regional control; the presence of distant metastases would shift management toward systemic or palliative therapies.

answer: For non-small cell lung cancer with separate pulmonary nodules in the contralateral lung (M1a), this finding classifies the disease as metastatic. Surgical resection is generally not indicated for M1a disease, and the described strategy of surgery after preoperative systemic therapy applies only to cases with nodules in the same or ipsilateral lung, not in the contralateral lung.

question: In a patient with metastatic (stage IV, M1) invasive breast cancer that is ER- and/or PR-positive and HER2-negative, who presents with rapid progression of liver metastases resulting in impaired hepatic function and clinical symptoms, should initial systemic therapy be prioritized over endocrine therapy, regardless of previous endocrine sensitivity?

nodes: Workup for Recurrent or Stage IV (M1) Disease (BINV-18)

•History and physical exam•Discuss goals of therapy, adopt shared decision-making, and document course of care • CBC • Comprehensive metabolic panel, including liver function tests and alkaline phosphatase • Imaging for systemic staging: ▸ Chest diagnostic CT ▸ contrast ▸ Abdomen ▸ pelvis diagnostic CT with contrast or MRI with contrast ▸ Brain MRI with contrast if suspicious CNS symptoms [hhh] ▸ Spine MRI with contrast if back pain or symptoms of cord compression ▸ Bone scan or sodium fluoride PET/CT (category 2B) ▸ Useful in certain circumstances FDG-PET/CT (consider FES-PET/CT for ER-positive disease) ▸ X-rays of symptomatic bones and long and weight-bearing bones abnormal on bone scan • Biomarker testing ▸ Biopsy of at least first recurrence of disease (consider re-biopsy if progression) [jjj] ▸ Evaluation of ER/PR and HER2 status [d] [iii] ▸ Comprehensive genomic and somatic profiling to identify candidates for targeted therapies [kkk] • Genetic counseling if patient is at risk for hereditary breast cancer [e] • Assess for distress [g]
Systemic Treatment of Recurrent Unresectable (local or regional) or Stage IV (M1) (BINV-21) and Supportive care
Recurrent unresectable (local or regional) or stage IV (M1) disease
Continue therapy until progression or unacceptable toxicity
For those with visceral crisis: Progression or unacceptable toxicity on first-line systemic therapy

Most patients will be candidates for multiple lines of systemic therapy to palliate advanced breast cancer. At each reassessment clinicians should assess value of ongoing treatment, the risks and benefits of an additional line of systemic therapy, patient performance status, and patient preferences through a shared decision-making process.
Consider no further cytotoxic therapy and Continue supportive care (See NCCN Guidelines for Palliative Care and NCCN Guidelines for Supportive Care)

answer: Yes. In the setting of visceral crisis—characterized by life-threatening organ dysfunction such as rapidly progressive liver metastases—initial systemic cytotoxic therapy is prioritized over endocrine therapy, irrespective of hormone receptor sensitivity or prior endocrine responsiveness, to rapidly control disease and stabilize organ function.

question: In a patient with stage IV, M1b non-small cell lung cancer who has limited distant metastases and a performance status of 3–4, is systemic therapy the recommended approach even in the presence of significant comorbidities such as severe cardiac dysfunction?

question: In a patient with localized, invasive, non-inflammatory, non-metastatic (M0) breast cancer who had a primary tumor larger than 5 cm, negative axillary lymph nodes, and underwent total mastectomy with surgical axillary staging, is chest wall radiotherapy still indicated if the patient did not receive preoperative systemic therapy?

question: In a patient with non-small cell lung cancer presenting with T4 tumor extension involving resectable invasion of the mediastinum (N0–1 disease), is concurrent chemoradiation still recommended if the patient has severely impaired pulmonary function tests (PFTs) not amenable to improvement?

nodes: Stage IIB (T3 invasion, N0) Stage IIIA (T4 extension, N0–1; T3, N1; T4, N0–1)

Evaluate for perioperative therapy, PFTs (if not previously done), Bronchoscopy, Pathologic mediastinal lymph node evaluation, Brain MRI with contrast, MRI with contrast of spine + thoracic inlet for superior sulcus lesions abutting the spine, subclavian vessels, or brachial plexus, FDG-PET/CT scan (if not previously done)
Chest wall, trachea/carina, or mediastinum; T3 invasion, N0–1; resectable T4 extension, N0–1; Stage IIIA (T4, N0–1) resectable
Surgical reevaluation including chest CT ± PET/CT

answer: Concurrent chemoradiation is generally contraindicated in patients with severely impaired pulmonary function because of the high risk of treatment-related morbidity and mortality. For such patients, alternative approaches such as systemic therapy alone or individualized, less intensive regimens should be considered.

question: For a patient with stage IIIA (T1–2, N2) non-small cell lung cancer who underwent definitive chemoradiation and currently has no clinical or radiographic evidence of disease, is brain MRI with contrast indicated as part of routine surveillance in the absence of neurological symptoms?

nodes: Stage IIIA (T1–2, N2; T3, N1); Stage IIIB (T3, N2); Margins positive

No evidence of clinical/radiographic disease • Stage I–II (primary treatment included surgery ± chemotherapy)  H&P and chest CTj ± contrast every 6 mo for 2–3 y, then H&P and a low-dose non–contrast-enhanced chest CT annually • Stage I–II (primary treatment included RT) or stage III or stage IV (oligometastatic with all sites treated with definitive intent)  H&P and chest CTj ± contrast every 3–6 mo for 3 y, then H&P and chest CT ± contrast every 6 mo for 2 y, then H&P and a low-dose non–contrast-enhanced chest CT annually  Residual or new radiographic abnormalities may require more frequent imaging • Smoking cessation advice, counseling, and pharmacotherapy • FDG-PET/CTkk or brain MRI is not routinely indicated • Cancer Survivorship Care (NSCL-G)
Recurrence • FDG-PET/CT • Brain MRI with contrastq

answer: No, routine brain MRI with contrast is not indicated for surveillance in asymptomatic patients with stage IIIA non-small cell lung cancer post-definitive chemoradiation and no evidence of disease. Imaging of the brain is reserved for cases with neurological symptoms or clinical suspicion of recurrence.

question: In a patient with non-small cell lung cancer staged as IIIB (T2, N3), if mediastinal N3 lymph node status has not yet been pathologically confirmed but imaging studies including FDG-PET/CT and brain MRI suggest N3 disease, is it appropriate to proceed directly to treatment for stage IIIB disease, or is pathological confirmation of N3 disease a necessary prerequisite before initiation of definitive treatment?

Stage IIIA (T1–2, N2); Stage IIIB (T3, N2)

Stage IIIB (T1–2, N3) Stage IIIC (T3, N3)

Treatment for Metastasis limited sites (NSCL-15) or distant disease (NSCL-18)

answer: Pathological confirmation of N3 lymph node involvement is a necessary prerequisite before initiating definitive treatment for stage IIIB (T2, N3) non-small cell lung cancer. Imaging studies alone are insufficient to establish the diagnosis, as invasive biopsy methods such as mediastinoscopy or EBUS are required to confirm N3 status for accurate staging and appropriate therapeutic planning.

question: In a patient with stage IVA non-small cell lung cancer presenting with malignant pleural effusion and confirmed ERBB2 (HER2) mutation, is local therapy such as pleurodesis sufficient as the sole treatment, or is it necessary to initiate systemic therapy targeting stage IV disease concurrently?

answer: Local therapy such as pleurodesis addresses symptoms from pleural effusion but is not sufficient as the sole treatment for stage IVA disease. Systemic therapy targeting stage IV non-small cell lung cancer, guided by molecular findings such as ERBB2 (HER2) mutation, is necessary and should be initiated concurrently with any local measures.

question: For a patient with Stage IA (T1abc, N0) non–small cell lung cancer who has positive surgical margins (R1 or R2), is it appropriate to proceed with radiotherapy as definitive local treatment if the patient is not a candidate for re-resection?

answer: Yes; for Stage IA (T1abc, N0) non–small cell lung cancer patients with positive margins (R1 or R2) who cannot undergo further surgical resection, radiotherapy is an accepted alternative local treatment, although it is considered a category 2B recommendation and may have less robust supporting evidence compared to re-resection.

question: In a patient with newly diagnosed non-small cell lung cancer presenting with multiple pulmonary lesions and an ECOG performance status of 2, but without previously documented biomarker testing, is it appropriate to initiate systemic therapy for metastatic disease without waiting for molecular results?

nodes: Stage IIB (T3 invasion, N0) Stage IIIA (T4 extension, N0–1; T3, N1; T4, N0–1)

Evaluate for perioperative therapy, PFTs (if not previously done), Bronchoscopy, Pathologic mediastinal lymph node evaluation, Brain MRI with contrast, MRI with contrast of spine + thoracic inlet for superior sulcus lesions abutting the spine, subclavian vessels, or brachial plexus, FDG-PET/CT scan (if not previously done)
Treatment for Metastasis limited sites (NSCL-15) or distant disease (NSCL-18)
Biomarker testing (NSCL-19) If not previously done • Brain MRI with contrast • FDG-PET/CT scan • Pathologic confirmation of metastatic lesion, if possible

answer: Systemic therapy for metastatic non-small cell lung cancer can be initiated in patients with multiple lesions and ECOG PS 0–2; however, current clinical practice requires biomarker testing prior to systemic treatment selection. Empiric therapy may occasionally proceed if rapid symptom control is necessary, but targeted or immunotherapy regimens should await molecular results whenever feasible.

question: In a patient with newly diagnosed stage IIIA non-small cell lung cancer (T1–2, N3), if mediastinal N3 involvement is confirmed only by FDG-PET/CT without pathologic verification via biopsy or mediastinoscopy, is it clinically justified to proceed directly to systemic therapy for metastatic disease?

answer: No, reliance solely on FDG-PET/CT for N3 mediastinal node involvement is insufficient to define metastatic disease; pathologic confirmation through biopsy or mediastinoscopy is required before systemic therapy is initiated, as imaging alone may produce false positives.

question: A patient with invasive, non-inflammatory, non-metastatic breast cancer is clinically staged as cT1c, cN0, and has HER2-positive disease. Is preoperative systemic therapy a justified approach in this case, or is it recommended only for cT2 or node-positive tumors?

nodes: Localized breast cancer: Invasive, non-inflammatory, non-metastatic (M0)
Additional Workup Prior to Preoperative Systemic Therapy (BINV-12)
cT2 or cN+ and M0 or cT1c, cN0 HER2-positive disease or cT1c, cN0 TNBC (For preoperative systemic therapy criteria, see BINV-M 1)

Axillary assessment with exam • Consider ultrasound • Percutaneous biopsy of suspicious nodes • CBC • Comprehensive metabolic panel, including liver function tests and alkaline phosphatase • Additional tests to consider as clinically indicated • Chest diagnostic CT ± contrast • Abdomen ± pelvis diagnostic CT with contrast or MRI with contrast • Bone scan or sodium fluoride PET/CT (category 2B) • FDG-PET/CT • Breast MRI (optional), with special consideration for mammographically occult tumors, if not previously done
For operable breast cancers: see Breast and Axillary Evaluation Prior to Preoperative Systemic Therapy (BINV-13)

Prior to preoperative systemic therapy, perform: • Core biopsy of breast with placement of image-detectable clips or marker(s), if not previously performed, should be performed prior to preoperative therapy to demarcate the tumor bed • Axillary imaging with ultrasound or MRI (if not previously done) and • Biopsy + marker placement recommended of the most suspicious and/or clinically positive axillary lymph node, if not previously done; only the most suspicious node should be marked and retrieved along with SLNs
Preoperative systemic therapy based on HR and HER2 status
Surgical Treatment and Adjuvant Therapy After Preoperative Systemic Therapy
Mastectomy and surgical axillary staging (BINV-D) ± reconstruction

answer: Preoperative systemic therapy is justified for cT1c, cN0, HER2-positive breast cancer. Its indication is not confined to cT2 or node-positive cases; HER2-positive status in cT1c tumors serves as an independent criterion warranting neoadjuvant systemic treatment.

question: For a patient with non–small cell lung cancer presenting with stage IIIC disease (T3, N3, M0) and confirmed mediastinal lymph node involvement via EBUS biopsy, does the selection of perioperative therapy implicitly require the absence of distant metastases on brain MRI and FDG-PET/CT imaging?

nodes: Stage IIIA (T1–2, N2); Stage IIIB (T3, N2)
Evaluate for perioperative therapy; PFTs (if not previously done); Bronchoscopy; Pathologic mediastinal lymph node evaluation; FDG-PET/CT scan (if not previously done); Brain MRI with contrast
Stage IIIB (T1–2, N3) Stage IIIC (T3, N3)

Stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) alone or Surgical resection, if symptomatic or warranted for diagnosis, followed by SRS or whole brain RT (WBRT)

answer: Yes. The use of perioperative therapy in stage IIIC (T3, N3, M0) non–small cell lung cancer is contingent on confirming M0 status, which by definition excludes distant metastases. Negative findings on brain MRI and FDG-PET/CT are necessary prerequisites before considering perioperative interventions in this population.

question: In a postmenopausal woman with ER-positive, HER2-negative, stage IV (M1) breast cancer without bone or visceral crisis, who has progressed on first-line endocrine therapy within one year, is immediate initiation of additional cytotoxic chemotherapy required, or is continuation of alternative lines of endocrine therapy still preferred until visceral crisis or unacceptable toxicity develops?

nodes: Workup for Recurrent or Stage IV (M1) Disease (BINV-18)

•History and physical exam•Discuss goals of therapy, adopt shared decision-making, and document course of care • CBC • Comprehensive metabolic panel, including liver function tests and alkaline phosphatase • Imaging for systemic staging: ▸ Chest diagnostic CT ▸ contrast ▸ Abdomen ▸ pelvis diagnostic CT with contrast or MRI with contrast ▸ Brain MRI with contrast if suspicious CNS symptoms [hhh] ▸ Spine MRI with contrast if back pain or symptoms of cord compression ▸ Bone scan or sodium fluoride PET/CT (category 2B) ▸ Useful in certain circumstances FDG-PET/CT (consider FES-PET/CT for ER-positive disease) ▸ X-rays of symptomatic bones and long and weight-bearing bones abnormal on bone scan • Biomarker testing ▸ Biopsy of at least first recurrence of disease (consider re-biopsy if progression) [jjj] ▸ Evaluation of ER/PR and HER2 status [d] [iii] ▸ Comprehensive genomic and somatic profiling to identify candidates for targeted therapies [kkk] • Genetic counseling if patient is at risk for hereditary breast cancer [e] • Assess for distress [g]
Systemic Treatment of Recurrent Unresectable (local or regional) or Stage IV (M1) (BINV-21) and Supportive care
Recurrent unresectable (local or regional) or stage IV (M1) disease
No visceral crisis and Prior endocrine therapy within 1 y
Continue endocrine therapy until progression or unacceptable toxicity
For those with visceral crisis: Progression or unacceptable toxicity on first-line systemic therapy

Most patients will be candidates for multiple lines of systemic therapy to palliate advanced breast cancer. At each reassessment clinicians should assess value of ongoing treatment, the risks and benefits of an additional line of systemic therapy, patient performance status, and patient preferences through a shared decision-making process.
Consider no further cytotoxic therapy and Continue supportive care (See NCCN Guidelines for Palliative Care and NCCN Guidelines for Supportive Care)

answer: Continuation of alternative lines of endocrine therapy remains preferred until the onset of visceral crisis or unacceptable toxicity. Immediate initiation of additional cytotoxic chemotherapy is not required in the absence of visceral crisis, as sequential endocrine therapies should be exhausted first in ER-positive, HER2-negative, postmenopausal metastatic breast cancer.

question: In a patient with stage IA (T1aN0) non-small cell lung cancer who has undergone surgical resection but has positive margins (R1), is definitive radiation therapy always required, or does re-resection remain the preferred option when feasible?

answer: For stage IA (T1aN0) non-small cell lung cancer with positive resection margins (R1), repeat surgical resection is preferred when feasible. Definitive radiation therapy is considered a secondary (category 2B) option if re-resection is not possible. Therefore, re-resection takes priority over radiation in the absence of surgical contraindications.

question: For a patient with stage I non-small cell lung cancer who underwent surgery with positive margins (R1/R2), if the patient has significant renal impairment precluding the use of contrast agents, is routine post-treatment surveillance with non–contrast-enhanced chest CT still appropriate for early detection of recurrence?

answer: Yes, non–contrast-enhanced chest CT remains appropriate for surveillance in stage I NSCLC patients after surgery, even with positive margins and renal impairment, as contrast enhancement is not mandatory for routine follow-up and does not compromise the ability to detect early recurrence.

question: In a patient with resectable non-small cell lung cancer staged as T2N2M0, who has undergone FDG-PET/CT and brain MRI showing no distant metastases, does initiation of systemic therapy without prior mediastinal lymph node biopsy assume that radiographic findings alone are sufficient for N2 confirmation?

answer: Yes, for a patient with SVC obstruction and a history of prior concurrent chemoradiation, placement of a superior vena cava stent remains an appropriate management to promptly relieve obstructive symptoms, regardless of previous chemoradiation.

question: For a patient with newly diagnosed stage IIIB (T3, N2) non-small cell lung cancer who presents with symptomatic superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction, and who has not previously received chemotherapy or radiation, is it appropriate to pursue concurrent chemoradiation rather than immediate SVC stent placement as the initial intervention?

answer: Routine use of FDG-PET/CT or brain MRI with contrast is not indicated during surveillance follow-up in this scenario without evidence of recurrence; standard follow-up should include history and physical examination and chest CT at specified intervals, reserving advanced imaging for suspicion of relapse or new symptoms.

question: In a patient with invasive, non-inflammatory, non-metastatic (M0) breast cancer, clinical stage cT2N0, who is HER2-negative and triple-negative, is preoperative systemic therapy indicated based on standard criteria, or should primary surgery be prioritized in this setting?

cT2 or cN+ and M0 or cT1c, cN0 HER2-positive disease or cT1c, cN0 TNBC (For preoperative systemic therapy criteria, see BINV-M 1)

Axillary assessment with exam • Consider ultrasound • Percutaneous biopsy of suspicious nodes • CBC • Comprehensive metabolic panel, including liver function tests and alkaline phosphatase • Additional tests to consider as clinically indicated • Chest diagnostic CT ± contrast • Abdomen ± pelvis diagnostic CT with contrast or MRI with contrast • Bone scan or sodium fluoride PET/CT (category 2B) • FDG-PET/CT • Breast MRI (optional), with special consideration for mammographically occult tumors, if not previously done
For operable breast cancers: see Breast and Axillary Evaluation Prior to Preoperative Systemic Therapy (BINV-13)

Prior to preoperative systemic therapy, perform: • Core biopsy of breast with placement of image-detectable clips or marker(s), if not previously performed, should be performed prior to preoperative therapy to demarcate the tumor bed • Axillary imaging with ultrasound or MRI (if not previously done) and • Biopsy + marker placement recommended of the most suspicious and/or clinically positive axillary lymph node, if not previously done; only the most suspicious node should be marked and retrieved along with SLNs
Preoperative systemic therapy based on HR and HER2 status
Surgical Treatment and Adjuvant Therapy After Preoperative Systemic Therapy
Mastectomy and surgical axillary staging (BINV-D) ± reconstruction
cN+ and ypN0: Strongly consider RT to the chest wall and comprehensive RNI with inclusion of any portion of the undissected axilla at risk.

answer: For a patient with cT2N0 breast cancer who is HER2-negative and triple-negative, preoperative systemic therapy is indicated according to current selection criteria. Primary surgery is not prioritized over neoadjuvant therapy in this scenario, as systemic treatment before surgery can improve pathologic response rates and guide further management.

answer: For resectable stage IIIA (T4, N1) non-small cell lung cancer with mediastinal invasion, initial systemic therapy or concurrent chemoradiation is generally prioritized over immediate surgical resection. This approach increases the likelihood of margin-negative (R0) resection, addresses micrometastatic disease, and allows for surgical reevaluation based on treatment response. Direct surgery is typically reserved for select cases without bulky disease or major invasion precluding complete resection.

For this stage and N3 involvement, non-surgical modalities such as chemoradiotherapy are standard; poor pulmonary reserve further contraindicates surgery due to high operative risk.

question: In a patient with stage IA peripheral non-small cell lung cancer (T1a-c, N0), if preoperative pulmonary function tests reveal severely impaired respiratory reserve, is surgical resection still considered the preferred primary treatment approach?

Surgery after preoperative systemic therapy, if planned

answer: For stage IA peripheral NSCLC, surgical resection is generally the standard primary treatment; however, in the presence of severely impaired pulmonary function, surgery is contraindicated due to high perioperative risk. In such cases, non-surgical options such as stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT) are preferred.
